docs.lead_paragraph: Positioning himself for a re-election campaign this fall, Gov. George E. Pataki today proposed a major expansion of health insurance for young New Yorkers as well as an acceleration of tax cuts and an expansion of anti-crime measures that he said had already enabled him to lead the state to ''the dawn of its greatest day.'' In his fourth annual State of the State address, a speech notably devoid of contentious initiatives, the Republican Governor cautiously previewed the economic and social themes that he is likely to use if, as widely expected, he runs for a second term: reducing taxes, cutting welfare and fighting crime.

headline.main: PATAKI PROPOSING HEALTH CARE PLAN FOR YOUNG PEOPLE

docs.abstract: Gov George E Pataki, in his fourth annual State of State address, proposes major expansion of health insurance for young New Yorkers as well as acceleration of tax cuts and expansion of anti-crime measures that he says have enabled him to lead state to 'dawn of its greatest day'; says health proposal would guarantee access to comprehensive health coverage for every child through age 18; proposes to more than double size of scheduled 1998 tax cut, to $1.2 billion; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-11 Iranian President Proposes Cultural Links to U.S. President Mohammed Khatami of Iran proposed cultural exchanges as a way to break down years of mistrust between his country and the United States, but ruled out government-to-government dialogue during an interview with the Cable News Network. docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton's 1996 re-election campaign showed that for an incumbent blessed with a healthy economy and strong poll numbers, an election year is the season for government by increment, not bold action. And Gov. George E. Pataki has learned the lesson well. In his annual State of the State Message today, the Governor hewed to the core conservative ideas that got him elected, attacking high taxes and crime, but with nothing like the striking proposals of his first three years in office: the death penalty, deep cuts in income and property taxes, and smaller budgets.

headline.main: Government by Increment: Pataki Speech Takes Few Chances

docs.abstract: Analysis of Gov George Pataki's State of the State Message says he hewed to core conservative ideas that got him elected, attacking high taxes and crime, but replaced the striking proposals of his first three years with a broad net of smaller, highly popular ideas; highlights of his speech involving tax cuts, health care, crime and education (M)
